value.title: 5 things you didn't know about Power BI Desktop
value.excerpt: Patrick shows you 5 things you didn't know about Power BI Desktop. Some potentially hidden things that may not be obvious and will help you out when creating Power BI reports within Power BI Desktop.  ******** LET'S CONNECT! ********  -- http://twitter.com/guyinacube -- http://twitter.com/awsaxton --

value.title: Analyze days from two months on one line chart in Power BI
value.excerpt: Have you struggled to compare data from two different time periods in Power BI? Does the data just continue on and not overlap? Patrick shows you how you can easily overlay the data for comparison.  Download sample: https://guyinacu.be/twomonthssample  📢 Become a member: https://guyinacu.be/membership

value.title: Avoid the full refresh with Incremental Refresh in Power BI (Premium)
value.excerpt: Is the full refresh of Incremental Refresh taking a long time? Or, even timing out? Patrick shows you how you can avoid the full refresh and refresh each partition individually when using Power BI Premium!  Handling deletes within Incremental Refresh in Power BI: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nKVrl0ec6uE

value.title: Deployment Pipelines give you more CONTROL (Power BI Premium)
value.excerpt: With Deployment Pipelines, you can control your application life cycle stages. Keep content in sync at the different stages of your development. Power BI Premium is required.  Documentation: https://docs.microsoft.com/power-bi/create-reports/deployment-pipelines-overview https://docs.microsoft.com/power-bi/create-reports/deployment-pipelines-process

value.title: Incremental Refresh with Power BI Premium
value.excerpt: In this video, Christian Wade joined Adam Saxton to discuss Incremental Refresh with Power BI Premium. You can use Incremental Refresh with Power BI Premium to take your dataset beyond 1GB and avoid failures such as timeouts.  Incremental Refresh with Power BI Premium documentation - https://docs.microsoft.com/power-bi/service-premium-incremental-refresh

value.title: Native Query: Be careful when using in Power BI
value.excerpt: Patrick looks at native query and why you should be careful when using it in Power BI. He looks at what native query is, what to consider when using it, and how to monitor what query folding, in Power Query, is or is not doing.  Guy in a Cube Courses: https://guyinacu.be/courses  ******** LET'S CONNECT!

value.title: Power BI Secure Embed - a no code / low code option
value.excerpt: In this video, Patrick looks at the new Power BI Secure Embed. If you have been using Publish to Web internally, you need to look at this feature as it is the perfect replacement that adds a secure option for easy, frictionless, embedding.  LET'S CONNECT!  Guy in a Cube -- https://guyinacube.com -- http://twitter.com/guyinacube

value.title: Power BI Tutorial: Dynamically Filter By Today's Date
value.excerpt: In this Power BI Tutorial, Patrick looks at how to dynamically filter by today's date. Using a date table, you can create a DAX measure that can then be used as a Power BI report-level filter to dynamically filter by today's date within Power BI Desktop.be  LET'S CONNECT!  Guy in a Cube -- https://guyinacube.com

value.title: Power BI: Use DAX to get relative dates
value.excerpt: Patrick looks at how you can get relative dates, in Power BI Desktop, without using the relative date slicer or relative date filters. You just need to sprinkle a little DAX into Power BI Desktop to get this going!  ******** LET'S CONNECT! ********  -- http://twitter.com/guyinacube -- http://twitter.com/awsaxton

value.title: Month over Month Calculation in Power BI using DAX
value.excerpt: When working with dates, one of the common types of analysis is period vs period, such as Year over year, and Month over month. In this article and video, I'll explain how you can use DAX to write calculations for month-over-month simply in any Power BI report. download the Power BI file and find the

value.title: Relationship in Power BI with Multiple Columns
value.excerpt: You can create relationships in Power BI between tables. Relationships are useful for some functions to work across multiple tables and produce the result. Relationship between tables also makes visualization and report elements more efficient, because the result of selection in one chart can affect
